channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Italy, One Man Begs for Asylum. Another Man Must Decide.
item.media:description: Two men from Bangladesh tried to fix a bicycle tire in June at the reception center in Calenzano, Italy, that they share with migrants from other nations.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: As Giorgio De Francesco, who oversees an asylum commission, hears migrants’ impassioned requests for protection, he grapples with knowing that he must vote against many of them.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Kurdish Militant Group Claims Responsibility for Deadly Istanbul Bombing
item.media:description: Coffins of police officers were carried on Sunday in Istanbul.
item.description: The Kurdistan Freedom Falcons said in a statement on Sunday that it had carried out the double suicide bombing in Turkey the night before that killed dozens and targeted the police.
item.dc:creator: SAFAK TIMUR

item.title: Buoyed by Donald Trump Win, Jerusalem Mayor Hopes to Get U.S. Embassy
item.media:description: Mayor Nir Barkat of Jerusalem says he is optimistic that when Donald J. Trump is president, he will move the United States Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, whose status is contested by Israel and the Palestinians.
item.description: Nir Barkat said that in a Trump administration, he expected the embassy to be moved from Tel Aviv “sooner rather than later.”
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Iran and Boeing Sign $16.6 Billion Deal on Sale of 80 Aircraft
item.media:description: A Boeing 747 belonging to Iran’s national airline at Mehrabad International Airport in Tehran in 2003.
item.description: The agreement, to be carried out over 10 years, may face opposition from supporters of President-elect Donald J. Trump in Congress.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Attack on Coptic Cathedral in Cairo Kills Dozens
item.media:description: The attack was the deadliest against Egypt’s Christian minority in years.
item.description: The bombing killed at least 25 people and was the deadliest attack against Egypt’s Christian minority in years.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH and NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: ISIS Close to Recapturing Palmyra From Syrian Forces
item.media:description: Syrian Army soldiers driving past the Arch of Triumph in Palmyra, in the Homs Governorate.
item.description: Losing the city for a second time would be a major blow for the Syrian government, which retook the city in March after 10 months of ISIS rule.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: As Turkey Cracks Down, Kurdish Mayors Pack Bags for Jail
item.media:description: Two women ran last month as the Turkish riot police used tear gas and plastic bullets to disperse protesters during a rally against the arrest of lawmakers of the Peoples’ Democratic Party in Istanbul.
item.description: Ankara’s clampdown on Kurdish politicians has been so thoroughgoing that it has left those who remain free expecting arrest at any moment.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Foes of Russia Say Child Pornography Is Planted to Ruin Them
item.media:description: Vladimir K. Bukovsky in his study at his home in Cambridge, England. Mr. Bukovsky was visited by police officers who had “received information about forbidden images” in his possession, he said.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: A K.G.B. dirty trick known as “kompromat,” the fabrication of compromising or illegal material, may have returned in a particularly noxious form.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Nelson Journal: With Flood of Urbanites, a Canadian Hippie Haven Tries to Keep Its Mellow
item.media:description: A late-night busker playing in Nelson, British Columbia. The recent influx of people to this compact town of 10,000 has led to an affordable housing crisis.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Nelson, British Columbia, has everything laid-back urban refugees priced out of other cities could want. Except housing.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: The Interpreter: How ‘Islands of Honesty’ Can Crush a System of Corruption
item.media:description: Former President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil, right, and former President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina at a meeting in São Paulo, Brazil, on Friday.
item.description: With the Parliament in South Korea voting to impeach President Park Geun-hye, the cavalcade of scandals can make it seem like the world’s politicians have suddenly become greedier en masse.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: With Uncertainties Roiling Washington and Seoul, What Next for North Korea?
item.media:description: Fireworks illuminated the sky during a rally against South Korea’s president, Park Geun-hye, in Seoul on Saturday.
item.description: South Korea, in the wake of the vote to impeach its president, may choose a new leader who pursues a more open diplomacy with the North.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Boko Haram Is Blamed for 2 Girl Suicide Bombers Near Market in Nigeria
item.description: Two girl suicide bombers died when they exploded Sunday in a crowded area near a market in Nigeria's northeastern city of Maiduguri, injuring 17 people, rescue officials said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Gambians Face Uncertainty After President Rejects His Defeat
item.media:description: Workers in Bijilo, Gambia, removed a poster of President Yahya Jammeh, who conceded the election and then reversed himself.
item.description: Adama Barrow, the victor, said he would try to convince President Yahya Jammeh that it was in Gambia’s “supreme interest” to transfer power smoothly.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: What in the World: Nazi Grave in Brazil Endures as Marker of Secret Plan to Colonize
item.media:description: A Nazi grave marker in a cemetery near Laranjal do Jari, Brazil. The alternate image has been enhanced for legibility, consistent with its original painting.
item.media:credit: Lúcio Costa Leite; Illustration by The New York Times
item.description: Known as the Guyana Project, an expedition to study the Amazon in 1935 turned into the pursuit of a German Guiana, an idea undone by malaria and other troubles.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Center-Left Party Poised to Regain Power in Romania
item.media:description: A woman cast her ballot as another voter exited the booth and an election official, right, looked on at a polling station in Sintesti, near Bucharest, Romania, on Sunday.
item.description: Despite recent scandals, the Social Democratic Party secured a large lead in parliamentary elections. The main question now is who will be prime minister.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET

item.title: Italy’s Foreign Minister Will Try to Form a New Government
item.description: Paolo Gentiloni hopes to lead Italy out of a political crisis that ensued with the recent resignation of Matteo Renzi as prime minister.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Istanbul Journal: In a Smoky Haze, Turks Cling to Their Cigarettes
item.media:description: Smokers with cigarettes and water pipes outside a cafe in Istanbul this month. Turkey’s efforts to impose restrictions and counteract its reputation for smoking have made little impact.
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.description: Turkey has made strong efforts to counteract its smoking habit, with measures nearly as strict as those in any Western country. But smokers resist.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: In Istanbul, 38 Killed in 2 Blasts Possibly Targeting Police Officers
item.media:description: Initial reports said that 20 police officers had been wounded in the attack outside Vodafone Arena Stadium in Istanbul. Turkish media later reported that more than a dozen officers had been killed.
item.description: Turkish officials also said 136 people were wounded in the explosions, which occurred outside a soccer stadium and in an adjacent park.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Canada’s $7 Billion Dam Tests the Limits of State Power
item.media:description: People against the Site C hydroelectric dam gathered on the property of Ken and Arlene Boon, farmers whose third-generation property is being expropriated for a Site C-related highway realignment that goes right through their house. “We feel railroaded,” Ms. Boon, 54, said.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: A fight over a hydroelectric project in British Columbia is pitting the government against a public demanding greater rights and political transparency.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.category: British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority

item.title: ‘We Are Dead Either Way’: Agonizing Choices for Syrians in Aleppo
item.media:description: Syrians leaving eastern Aleppo on Saturday encountered a checkpoint run by pro-government forces.
item.description: As pro-government forces drove into the city’s rebel-held section, civilians faced escalating attacks and weighed dangerous options to flee.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Suicides Reported in India After Death of Jayalalithaa Jayaram
item.media:description: A supporter of Jayalalithaa Jayaram, the Tamil Nadu leader who died on Monday, cried next to Ms. Jayaram’s burial place in Chennai, India.
item.description: Ms. Jayaram, the leader of the governing party of the state of Tamil Nadu, was beloved by her followers and inspired frenzied emotions in some of them.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Indonesian Police Arrest 4 Near Jakarta as Terrorist Plot Is Foiled
item.description: The police said they believed that the suspects, one of whom was a woman thought to be a potential suicide bomber, were planning an attack on a presidential palace this weekend.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Wall Street Is Europe’s Landlord. And Tenants Are Fighting Back.
item.media:description: A local child rode a bike in Tyrrelstown, a suburb northwest of Dublin, where dozens of tenants had been served with eviction notices after being told their homes had been purchased by a Goldman Sachs investment fund.
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.description: Huge profits and dubious tax strategies have made investment firms in America the object of frustration and anger, as many Europeans face eviction and fear becoming homeless.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Xinjiang, Tense Chinese Region, Adopts Strict Internet Controls
item.media:description: A market in Kashgar in the Xinjiang region of China, in 2015. New rules appear to be aimed at criminalizing people in Xinjiang who post online about ethnic conflict.
item.description: The regulations punish people for spreading “false information” in the far western region, which has grappled with ethnic violence.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: With Mass Protests, South Koreans Wield a Familiar Weapon in a New Era
item.media:description: Riot police officers used tear gas to disperse protesting students during violent clashes at Yonsei University in September 1987.
item.description: In 1987, the demonstrations were far more violent than those of today. But the passions of those demanding change still burn bright.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN CHIRA

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Standing Up to a Strongman
item.media:description: A rally in suburban Quezon near Manila, on Nov. 30, to protest the re-burial of the late Ferdinand Marcos at the Heroes’ Cemetery.
item.description: The people of the Philippines are taking to the streets to protest their brutal new president.
item.dc:creator: MIGUEL SYJUCO
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How Islam Can Fight the Patriarchy
item.media:description: A demonstration in Istanbul last month against a proposed bill that would overturn convictions for sexual assault in Turkey.
item.description: The Turkish government thought it could get a regressive law pardoning statutory rape on the books. Islam was the solution.
item.dc:creator: RIADA ASIMOVIC AKYOL

item.title: Editorial: Russia’s Hand in America’s Election
item.media:description: Vladimir Putin at the Kremlin last month.
item.description: Why would President-elect Trump object to a thorough, bipartisan probe into Russian meddling?
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
